sen.j: つくばい（蹲踞、蹲）とは日本庭園の添景物の一つで露地（茶庭）に設置される。
sen.e: A tsukubai (蹲踞, 蹲) is one of facilities for Japanese traditional gardens and installed in an entry garden to a teahouse.
A tsukubai (蹲踞, 蹲) is one type of facility for Japanese traditional gardens and is installed in an entry garden to a teahouse.
A tsukubai is one of facilities for Japanese traditional gardens and installed in an entry garden to a teahouse.
sen.cmt: (蹲踞, 蹲) を削除しました。

sen.j: 茶室に入る前に、手を清めるために置かれた背の低い手水鉢につくばいの構成および役石をおいて趣を加えたもの。
sen.e: It includes a low-height Chozubachi (basin) provided for visitors to purify their hands before entering the teahouse, and several Yaku-ishis (functional stones) arranged around the chozubachi.
It includes a low-height Chozubachi (basin) provided for visitors to purify their hands before entering the teahouse, and several Yaku-ishis (functional stones) arranged around the chozubachi.
It includes a low-height chozubachi (basin) provided for visitors to purify their hands before entering the teahouse, and several yaku-ishis (functional stones) arranged around the chozubachi.

sen.j: 手水で手を洗うとき「つくばう（しゃがむ）」ことからその名がある。
sen.e: The term Tsukubai literally means "stooping", and it is named from the fact that one has to stoop down to wash the hands using the chozubachi.
The term Tsukubai literally means "stooping", and it is so named because one has to stoop down to wash one's hands using the chozubachi.
The term tsukubai literally means "stooping", and it is so named because one has to stoop down to wash one's hands using the chozubachi.

sen.j: もともと茶道の習わしで、客人が這いつくばるように身を低くして、手を清めたのが始まりである。
sen.e: It is originated from a tea ceremony custom of visitors purifying their hands while stooping down.
It is originated from a tea ceremony custom of visitors purifying their hands while stooping down.
It is originated from a tea ceremony custom of visitors purifying their hands while stooping down.

sen.j: 茶事を行うための茶室という特別な空間に向かうための結界としても作用する。
sen.e: It also serves as a gate to enter a special area for tea ceremony, or the teahouse.
It also serves as a gate to enter a special area for tea ceremony, or the teahouse.
It also serves as a gate to enter a special area for tea ceremony, or the teahouse.

sen.j: 一般に、使用するのにつくばう必要のある高さのものをつくばいと言う。
sen.e: Those having a height which requires visitors to stoop down to use, are commonly called as a tsukubai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Those having a height which requires visitors to stoop down to use them are commonly called tsukubai.
Those having a height which requires visitors to stoop down to use them are commonly called tsukubai.

sen.j: 茶室に添えられる本格的なつくばいは、「手水鉢（水鉢）」を中心に、「前石」「手燭石」「湯桶石」（この3つの石を“役石”という）、「水門（海）」で構成されている。
sen.e: A traditional tsukubai provided beside a teahouse includes a chozubachi (mizubachi) at the center, three Yaku-ishis (a Mae-ishi, a Teshoku-ishi, and a Yuoke-ishi), and a Suimon (Umi).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A traditional tsukubai provided beside a teahouse includes a chozubachi (mizubachi) at the center, three Yaku-ishis (a Mae-ishi, a Teshoku-ishi, and a Yuoke-ishi), and a Suimon (Umi).
A traditional tsukubai provided beside a teahouse includes a "chozubachi (mizubachi) "at the center, three "yaku-ishis (a mae-ishi, a teshoku-ishi, and a yuoke-ishi)", and a "suimon (umi)".

sen.j: 手水鉢（ちょうずばち）
sen.e: Chozubachi
Chozubachi
Chozubachi

sen.j: 水鉢（みずばち）とも。
sen.e: It is also called as a Mizubachi (water bowl)
It is also called a Mizubachi (water bowl)
It is also called a mizubachi (water bowl)

sen.j: 茶事の時に客人は席入りする前にここから柄杓一杯の水をとり、手を洗う事によって身を清める。
sen.e: During tea ceremony, visitors purify themselves by washing their hands using a scoop of water from the chozubachi before entering the teahouse.
During tea ceremony, visitors purify themselves by washing their hands using a scoop of water from the chozubachi before entering the teahouse.
During tea ceremony, visitors purify themselves by washing their hands using a scoop of water from the chozubachi before entering the teahouse.

sen.j: 前石（まえいし）
sen.e: Mae-ishi
Mae-ishi
Mae-ishi

sen.j: 手水鉢の手前正面の石。
sen.e: It is a front stone placed forwardly of the chozubachi.
It is a front stone placed forward of the chozubachi.
It is a front stone placed forward of the chozubachi.

sen.j: 手水を使う際に乗る。
sen.e: Visitors step on the stone when they wash their hands.
Visitors step on the stone when they wash their hands.
Visitors step on the stone when they wash their hands.

sen.j: （その更に手前に石が置かれている場合がある。
sen.e: (In some cases, there is provided another stone forwardly of the Mae-ishi.
(In some cases, another stone is provided forward of the Mae-ishi.
(In some cases, another stone is provided forward of the mae-ishi.

sen.j: 飛石という。
sen.e: It is called as a Tobi-ishi.
It is called a Tobi-ishi.
It is called a tobi-ishi.

sen.j: 手燭石（てしょくいし）
sen.e: Teshoku-ishi
Teshoku-ishi
Teshoku-ishi

sen.j: 手水鉢の左側（※）の石。
sen.e: It is a stone placed to the left (*) of the chozubachi.
It is a stone placed to the left (*) of the chozubachi.
It is a stone placed to the left (*) of the chozubachi.

sen.j: 夜の茶会時に灯り（手燭など）を置く。
sen.e: During night tea ceremony, a light (a candlestick, for example) is placed on the stone.
During night tea ceremony, a light (a candlestick, for example) is placed on the stone.
During night tea ceremony, a light (a candlestick, for example) is placed on the stone.

sen.j: 湯桶石（ゆおけいし）
sen.e: Yuoke-ishi
Yuoke-ishi
Yuoke-ishi

sen.j: 手水鉢の右側（※）の石。
sen.e: It is a stone placed to the right (*) of the chozubachi.
It is a stone placed to the right (*) of the chozubachi.
It is a stone placed to the right (*) of the chozubachi.

sen.j: 冬など寒中の茶会時に湯桶を置く。
sen.e: When it is cold, a hot water bowl is placed on the stone for tea ceremony.
When it is cold, a hot water bowl is placed on the stone for tea ceremony.
When it is cold, a hot water bowl is placed on the stone for tea ceremony.

sen.j: 水門（すいもん）
sen.e: Suimon
Suimon
Suimon

sen.j: 海（うみ）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called as an Umi.
It is also called an Umi.
It is also called as an umi.

sen.j: 上記の手水鉢と役石に囲まれた低い部分。
sen.e: It is an area on the ground surrounded by the chozubachi and yaku-ishis.
It is an area on the ground surrounded by the chozubachi and yaku-ishis.
It is an area on the ground surrounded by the chozubachi and yaku-ishis.

sen.j: こぼれた手水を受けるために、砂利などを敷き詰めている。
sen.e: It is covered with gravel, etc. in order to deal with water spilled over the chozubachi.
It is covered with gravel, etc. in order to handle water spilled over the chozubachi.
It is covered with gravel, etc. in order to handle water spilled over the chozubachi.

sen.j: ※ 手燭石と湯桶石の左右は､茶道の流派によって異なる。
sen.e: * The left and right positioning of the teshoku-ishi and the yuoke-ishi varies depending on the school of tea ceremony.
* The left and right positioning of the teshoku-ishi and the yuoke-ishi varies depending on the school of tea ceremony.
* The left and right positioning of the teshoku-ishi and the yuoke-ishi varies depending on the school of tea ceremony.

sen.j: 縁先手水鉢
sen.e: Ensaki-chozubachi
Ensaki-chozubachi
Ensaki-chozubachi

sen.j: 建物の縁側で手水を使うために置かれた手水鉢を縁先手水鉢、または飾り鉢前という。
sen.e: A chozubachi, provided near a veranda of a building, for washing hands is called as an Ensaki-chozubachi or Kazaribachimae.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A chozubachi, provided near a veranda of a building, for washing hands is called an Ensaki-chozubachi or Kazaribachimae.
A chozubachi, provided near a veranda of a building, for washing hands is called an ensaki-chozubachi or kazaribachimae.

sen.j: つくばいと違い縁側で立ったまま使用する。
sen.e: Unlike the tsukubai, the ensaki-chozubachi can be used while standing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Unlike the tsukubai, the ensaki-chozubachi can be used while standing.
Unlike the tsukubai, the ensaki-chozubachi can be used while standing.

sen.j: そのため手水鉢は背の高いもの、あるいは背の低いものは台石に乗せたものを選ぶ。
sen.e: For this reason, a tall chozubachi is commonly used as an ensaki-chozubachi, and if a low height one is used, it is placed on a stone stand.
For this reason, a tall chozubachi is commonly used as an ensaki-chozubachi, and if one of low height is used, it is placed on a stone stand.
For this reason, a tall chozubachi is commonly used as an ensaki-chozubachi, and if one of low height is used, it is placed on a stone stand.

sen.j: 縁先手水鉢の役石には以下の4点がある。
sen.e: Yaku-ishis for the ensaki-chozubachi includes the followings.
Yaku-ishis for the ensaki-chozubachi include the following.
Yaku-ishis for the ensaki-chozubachi include the following four types of stones.

sen.j: 蟄石（かがみいし）
sen.e: Kagami-ishi
Kagami-ishi
Kagami-ishi

sen.j: 蟄石は濡れ縁の下に置かれる水返しの石であり鉢からこぼれた水が縁の板に飛び散るのを防ぐ役割がある。
sen.e: A kagami-ishi is a stone placed between the ensaki-chozubachi and the open veranda in order to prevent water spilled over the ensaki-chozubachi from wetting the veranda.
A kagami-ishi is a stone placed between the ensaki-chozubachi and the open veranda in order to prevent water spilled over the ensaki-chozubachi from wetting the veranda.
A kagami-ishi is a stone placed between the ensaki-chozubachi and the open veranda in order to prevent water spilled over the ensaki-chozubachi from wetting the veranda.

sen.j: 青石など他の役石とは石質が異なるものを使用する。
sen.e: Stones having characteristics different from those of other yaku-ishis, such as Ao-ishi (blue stone), are used.
Stones having characteristics different from those of other yaku-ishis, such as Ao-ishi (blue stone), are used.
Stones having characteristics different from those of other yaku-ishis, such as ao-ishi (blue stone), are used.

sen.j: 水汲み石
sen.e: Nizukumi-ishi
Nizukumi-ishi
Mizukumi-ishi

sen.j: 水汲み石は貴人の手水の時に、従者が水を汲んで差し出すときに乗る石である。
sen.e: It is a stone on which an attendant steps when he or she serves a scoop of water to his or her master to wash the hands.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is a stone on which an attendant steps when he or she serves a scoop of water to his or her master to wash the hands.
It is a stone on which an attendant steps when he or she serves a scoop of water to his or her master to wash the hands.

sen.j: 天端が平らかなものを使用する。
sen.e: Those stones having a flat top surface are used.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Those stones having a flat top surface are used.
Those stones having a flat top surface are used.

sen.j: 清浄石（せいじょういし）
sen.e: Seijo-ishi
Seijo-ishi
Seijo-ishi

sen.j: 清浄石は覗き石ともいわれ水汲み石との調和のために配される。
sen.e: It is a stone which is also called as a Nozoki-ishi, and provided to maintain a balance with the Mizukumi-ishi.
It is a stone which is also called a Nozoki-ishi, and is provided to maintain a balance with the Mizukumi-ishi.
It is a stone which is also called a nozoki-ishi, and is provided to maintain a balance with the mizukumi-ishi.

sen.j: 水揚げ石
sen.e: Mizuage-ishi
Mizuage-ishi
Mizuage-ishi

sen.j: 水揚げ石は手水鉢の水の取替えや清掃のときに使用される石である。
sen.e: It is a stone used for cleaning, or replacing the water of, the chozubachi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is a stone used for cleaning, or replacing the water of, the chozubachi.
It is a stone used for cleaning, or replacing the water of, the chozubachi.

sen.j: 鉢の後方に置かれ飛び石と連続することが多い。
sen.e: It is often placed rearwardly of the chozubachi and arranged in a continuous manner with the Tobi-ishi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is often placed rearward of the chozubachi and arranged in a continuous manner with the Tobi-ishi.
It is often placed rearward of the chozubachi and arranged in a continuous manner with the tobi-ishi.

sen.j: これらの役石の置き方は設置場所が縁側の左端か右端か、袖垣の近くかで左右が逆になる。
sen.e: These yaku-ishis may be arranged the other way around depending on whether the installation site is to the left or to the right of the veranda and whether the installation site is close to a sodegaki (low fence flanking the entrance).

These yaku-ishis may be arranged the other way around, depending on whether the installation site is to the left or to the right of the veranda and whether the installation site is close to a sodegaki (low fence flanking the entrance).

These yaku-ishis may be arranged the other way around, depending on whether the installation site is to the left or to the right of the veranda and whether the installation site is close to a sodegaki (low fence flanking the entrance).

sen.j: なお縁側から鉢までの距離は75 cm程度がよいとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the distance between the veranda and the chozubachi is preferably about 75 cm.
It is said that the distance between the veranda and the chozubachi is preferably about 75 cm.
